ObesityA disorder involving excessive body fat that increases the risk of health problems.
Childhood obesityA condition in which a child is significantly overweight for his or her age and height.
EsophagitisInflammation that damages the tube running from the throat to the stomach (esophagus).
Hiatal herniaA condition in which part of the stomach pushes up through the diaphragm muscle.
Barrett's esophagusDamage to the lower portion of the tube that connects the mouth and stomach (esophagus).
Acute BronchitisInflammation of the lining of bronchial tubes, which carry air to and from the lungs.
Metabolic syndromeA cluster of conditions that increase the risk of heart disease, stroke, and diabetes.
GastritisAny of a group of conditions in which the stomach lining is inflamed.
LaryngitisAn inflammation of the voice box from overuse, irritation, or infection.
AsthmaA condition in which a person's airways become inflamed, narrow and swell, and produce extra mucus, which makes it difficult to breathe.
Sjögren's syndromeAn immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth.
Stomach ulcerA sore that develops on the lining of the esophagus, stomach, or small intestine.
BulimiaA serious eating disorder marked by binging, followed by methods to avoid weight gain.
Heart attackA blockage of blood flow to the heart muscle.
Irritable bowel syndromeAn intestinal disorder causing pain in the belly, gas, diarrhea, and constipation.
GallstonesA hardened deposit within the fluid in the gallbladder, a small organ under the liver.

A digestive disease in which stomach acid or bile irritates the food pipe lining.This is a chronic disease that occurs when stomach acid or bile flows into the food pipe and irritates the lining. Acid reflux and heartburn more than twice a week may indicate GERD.Very commonMore than 3 million US cases per yearTreatable by a medical professionalUsually self-diagnosableLab tests or imaging rarely requiredMedium-term: resolves within monthsConsult a doctor for medical adviceSources:  Mayo Clinic and others. Learn more

Usually self-diagnosableSymptoms include burning pain in the chest that usually occurs after eating and worsens when lying down.Consult a doctor for medical adviceSources:  Mayo Clinic and others. Learn more   More symptoms

Treatment consists of self care and antacidsRelief from lifestyle changes and over-the-counter medications is usually temporary. Stronger medication may be needed. Self-careElevate head of bed, Dietary modification, and Weight loss  MedicationsAntacid, Proton-pump inhibitor, and Diarrhea medication Consult a doctor for medical adviceSources:  Mayo Clinic and others. Learn more   More about treatments
